creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: Khmer style of the Bayon; frontal stance; probably had extended hands; narrow shoulders and wider hips; eyes are closed; physiognomy relaxed; sublime expression
text: Prajñāpāramitā, the goddess of transcendent wisdom, is a personification of a holy text by the same name. In Tantric Buddhism, Prajñāpāramitā is believed to be the mother of all Buddhas. She belongs to a form of Buddhism practiced in Cambodia and Nepal. In Cambodia, however, the identities of god and ruler blurred under King Jayavarman VII (r.1181–1215), who made Buddhism the official state religion. He identified his mother with Prajñāpāramitā and represented himself as the Buddha, so that sculptures possessed a dual function of representing the divine and the ruler’s divine power.
title: Prajnaparamita
